summary: This document is an email chain from December 3, 2019, between U.S. Department of Justice personnel, including an Attaché at the U.S. Embassy in London and an Assistant U.S. Attorney from the Southern District of New York. The emails discuss coordinating a call regarding logistical questions for the Jeffrey Epstein investigation, specifically noting UK news about DOJ interest in Prince Andrew.

persons.name: Prince Andrew
persons.context: Mentioned as the subject of news in the UK regarding U.S. Department of Justice interest, within the context of the Epstein investigation.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The investigation into Jeffrey Epstein is the subject of the coordination efforts discussed in the email chain.

connections.description: LS, a DOJ Attaché in London, is being contacted by an Assistant U.S. Attorney from the SDNY to coordinate a call for the Epstein investigation team.
The document references news about DOJ interest in Prince Andrew in connection with the Jeffrey Epstein investigation.

events.title: Coordination for Epstein Investigation Call
events.description: U.S. prosecutors from the Southern District of New York reach out to a DOJ Attaché in London to schedule a call to ask logistical questions regarding the Jeffrey Epstein investigation.

locations.address: United States Embassy, 33 Nine Elms Lane, London SW11 7US
locations.context: Work location of the DOJ Attaché (LS) involved in the correspondence.
Location of the U.S. Embassy and where news about DOJ interest in Prince Andrew is reported.
Jurisdiction of the prosecutors working on the Epstein investigation.

keyFacts: In December 2019, U.S. prosecutors from the SDNY were actively coordinating with a DOJ Attaché in London regarding the Jeffrey Epstein investigation.
The email specifically references 'quite a bit of news in the UK about FBUDOJ interest in Prince Andrew,' indicating ongoing investigative interest in him at that time.
The communication is focused on logistical coordination for a call, suggesting operational planning between U.S. and UK-based law enforcement officials.
The document shows the investigation was active and involved international coordination several months after Epstein's death in August 2019.
